raw_text:
Nat Insurance to rise, say Tories
 
 National Insurance will be raised if Labour wins the next election, Tory leader Michael Howard has claimed.
 
 Tony Blair has said he does not want higher tax rates for top earners but on Wednesday said other tax promises would be left to Labour's manifesto. Prime minister's questions also saw Mr Blair predict that new plans would probably cut net immigration. He attacked Tory plans to process asylum claims abroad - but Mr Howard said Labour had proposed the idea too.
 
 The Commons questions session again saw the leaders of the two biggest parties shape up for the forthcoming election campaign. The Tories have promised £4bn in tax cuts but have yet to say where they will fall. Mr Howard pointed to the Institute for Fiscal Studies' predictions that Labour will need to increase taxes to cover an £11bn gap in its spending plans. He accused ministers of wasting money on unsuccessful attempts to curb bad behaviour and truancy in schools and on slow asylum processing. It was no good Mr Blair claiming tax pledges were being left to the manifesto as he had given one to MPs on Tuesday about the top rate of income tax, argued Mr Howard. Pointing to national insurance, he added: "Everyone knows tax will go up under Labour: isn't it now clear which tax it would be?"
 
 Mr Blair instead hailed Labour's achievement in using a strong economy to invest in public services. "When we have money not only going into extra teachers and nurses but equipment in schools and hospitals, that money is not wasted," he said. On the tax questions, he added: "We will make commitments on tax at the time of the manifesto." Home Secretary Charles Clarke this week published plans for a new points system for economic migrants, with only high-skilled workers allowed into the UK from outside the European Union.
 
 Mr Blair said abuses would be weeded out and chain migration, where families automatically get the right to settle with immigrant workers, would end. That would probably create a fall in the migrant numbers, he said. The prime minister ridiculed the Tory plans for asylum quotas and for processing all asylum claims overseas. He challenged the Tories on which country would house their processing centres - what he called a "fantasy island". Mr Howard read from a letter about the government's own plans at the European Council of Ministers for processing asylum seekers outside the EU. But Mr Blair said: "All the other countries could not agree on the way forward, nor could the UN."
llama3.2:1b: Tory leader Michael Howard claimed that National Insurance will rise if Labour wins the next election.
Tony Blair disagreed, saying no higher tax rates for top earners but promising other plans would be left to Labour's manifesto.
The two leaders clashed over tax promises and asylum processing.
The Tories have promised £4bn in tax cuts, while the Institute for Fiscal Studies predicts Labour needs to increase taxes to cover an £11bn gap in spending.
Howard accused ministers of wasting money on truancy efforts.
Blair defended Labour's use of a strong economy to invest in public services.

The Institute for Fiscal Studies predicts an £11bn gap in Labour's spending plans, which would require tax increases.
The two leaders clash over tax cuts and immigration policies, with Blair proposing a new points system to limit economic migrants.

Tony Blair defended Labour's investment in public services, promising tax commitments only in their manifesto.
He also announced a new points system for economic migrants aimed at reducing immigration and ending chain migration.
Mr Blair criticized Tory proposals to process asylum claims abroad and suggested that such plans are unrealistic and unfeasible.

tinyllama:1.1b: In their responses to questions during Prime Minister's Questions in the House of Commons, Tony Blair and his leader, Michael Howard, both emphasized their commitment to raising taxes for high-earning citizens as part of the forthcoming election campaign.

Meanwhile, Tony Blair stressed that national insurance would go up under Labour's economic strategy, while Charles Clark, the Home Secretary, published plans for a new points system for economic migrants and promised to weed out abuses and end chain migration.

However, Mr Howard read from a letter about their own plans on the issue of asylum seekers outside the EU.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The text describes a political discussion between two prominent politicians - Tony Blair from Labour and Michael Howard from the Tories.
They are discussing the topic of National Insurance and how to raise it if Labour wins the next election.

In order to summarize this information, we will focus on the key points: 

1.
National Insurance will be raised if Labour wins the next election, according to Michael Howard.
Tony Blair claims that new plans would probably cut net immigration.
The Tories have promised £4 billion in tax cuts but need to find ways to offset an £11 billion budget gap.
Michael Howard suggests that Labour has proposed unsuccessful ideas for increasing taxes, such as processing asylant claims abroad or increasing the top rate of income tax.
The Conservatives have promised to spend £4 billion on tax cuts and have yet to say where they will fall in their manifesto.
Tony Blair has criticized the Tories for wasting money, stating that Labour would need to increase taxes if they were elected.
Michael Howard is accused of wasting money by increasing public spending and slowing down asylum processing, a point he disputed vehemently.

In contrast, Tony Blair argues that investment in public services during a strong economy shows responsible spending on equipment for schools and hospitals.
He believes Labour will make commitments on taxes at the time of their manifesto.
Meanwhile, Charles Clarke has proposed a new points system for economic migrants that will prioritize only high-skilled workers from outside the EU.
He also suggests ending chain migration, which he sees as an abuse of the immigration system.

chatgpt-4o-latest: Tory leader Michael Howard claimed that National Insurance would rise if Labour won the next election.
Tony Blair stated he did not want higher tax rates for top earners but left other tax promises to Labour's manifesto.

During Prime Minister's Questions, Blair predicted new plans would reduce net immigration and criticized Tory proposals to process asylum claims abroad, which Howard argued Labour had also considered.
The Tories pledged £4bn in tax cuts but did not specify details, while Howard cited the Institute for Fiscal Studies' prediction that Labour would need to raise taxes to cover an £11bn spending gap.
Blair defended Labour’s investment in public services and deferred tax commitments to the manifesto.
He also announced a new points-based immigration system to limit low-skilled migration and end chain migration.

Blair dismissed Tory asylum plans as unrealistic, while Howard pointed to Labour’s own past proposals for processing asylum seekers outside the EU, which Blair said had failed due to lack of international agreement.
